div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Freeman's report on the trade and commerce of Alexandria for 1904, just issued, is highly interesting reading, more especially for those who are perplexed by the fact that British trade seems to be gradually losing the largest share of Egyptian imports. The wonderful prosperity of Egypt is, we believe, better realised on the Continent than at home, and the Continental manufacturer and merchant are naturally eager to make the most of so tempting a market. There are openings without number for trade in Egypt, but if British manufacturers are to find their way into these openings they must have agents on the spot and send more and better trained commercial travellers. Local requirements must be carefully studied and learned, to get a market. To hold it, regular visits at fixed intervals are necessary. Mr. Freeman gives us an illustration of these points which we quote:-- "The agents at Alexandria of a British firm dealing in carpenters' and blacksmiths' tools, and also in Sheffield goods in general, wrote to this Consulate as follows : 'The difficulty with our principals arises from the fact that the native does not use the same tools as the British workman. Many modifications and additions have consequently to be made so as to adapt the tools to what is required on our markets. If it were a question of a few articles only, the difficulty could easily be overcome by sending home samples, but as there are a thousand and probably more lines that have to be attended to you will easily understand how impossible it is for an agent who is neither a carpenter nor a blacksmith to send them all the particulars they want......The British firms do not take the trouble or care to incur the expense of sending out competent men to see what others are doing.' "

Not only do our firms not send out enough competent men, but, if we are to take up the hint dropped in Lord Cromer's recent speech, they sometimes send ill-mannered representatives. Speaking on the subject, Lord Cromer remarked that "we have to compete with the foreigner not only in respect of quality of goods but as regards tact, judgment, and conciliatory address." In fact, the British commercial traveller in Egypt must be a linguist and something of a diplomatist, if he is to succeed, while his employer must abandon his highly conservative attitude or lose ground to his foreign rivals. If we take the case of credit we discover at once that the foreigner allowing six months is far more likely to succeed in getting orders than the Briton who usually allows one month and rarely more than three. It is hopeless to struggle against the conditions of trade in Egypt, and firms that refuse to give long credit are likely enough in the long run to fail to maintain themselves in the market. Our imported articles are as a rule well-finished and of a high class, our firms have a good reputation, and our travellers are, as a rule, well paid, and yet we fail to gain ground because British manufacturers will no more believe their "man on the spot'' than the British public will believe an expert.

div.head:
THE "POTEMKIN."
INHABITANTS OF THEODOSIA PANIC-STRICKEN.
MUTINEERS SHOT.

div.p: The mutineers summoned the authorities on board, and demanded 500 tons of coal, provisions and tobacco, within 24 hours ; otherwise the town will be bombarded. They requested the Mayor to distribute to the inhabitants proclamations demanding the cessation of the war and the convocation of the Zemstvos, and exhorting the people to join the revolution. The inhabitants are panic-stricken, and are fleeing from the town. The municipality has decided to deliver the provisions, but not the coal, as there is none in the town. (Reuter.)
The majority of the inhabitants have left, believing that the "Potemkin" would bombard the town. The Sevastopol fleet has left to attack the "Potemkin." (Havas.)

The authorities have removed the population and only the troops and the police remain. A boat from the "Potemkin," approaching the shore this morning, was received by infantry fire and two other crew were killed. The 'Potemkin" then fired a shell over the town, but without doing any damage, and withdrew to the offing. Yesterday she overhauled a Russian merchantman and took off her cargo of cattle, provisions, and money. The Black Sea trade is paralyzed. ( Reuter.)
Sixty-seven of the ringleaders of the "Pobiedonosets" have been removed to the prison at Kertch ; it is believed that they will be shot. (Reuter.)
Forty-five of the mutineers of the "Pobiedonosets" have been shot. (Havas.)

div.head: NATIVE PRESS OPINIONS. LORD CROMER'S SPEECH.
div.p: In discussing Lord Cromer's speech, "Al Moayad" remarks that the better the relations between Abdeen and Buckingham Palace, the better for Egypt, and that the attitude of the extremists, whose idea of patriotism is a systematic opposition to all that has to do with the Occupation, is brainless and even opposed to the principles of the Koran. With Lord Cromer's four conditions the "Moayad" expresses its agreement subject to one or two reservations. While admitting that a direct control of Egyptian affairs by Parliament would injure Egypt, it remarks that Parliament must never lose its control of what are, after all, its agents in Egypt, and must be able to check any abuse of their powers. In this connection, it is earnestly to be desired that some means existed of bringing the Egyptian point of view before Parliament as clearly as Lord Cromer's point of view is set forth in the Blue-books. The caution in the introduction of Western ideas must not be exaggerated, for Egypt has made great strides, and finally, while there is no question of Lord Cromer's sincere devotion to the good of Egypt, many of his projects have been diverted from their end by those charged to carry them out.

"Al Lewa" expresses its disagreement with "Al Moayad's" views. Opposition to the British Occupation is an absolute necessity, and it is strange that ' Al Moayad,''''after 14 years in opposition, should abandon its policy and support Lord Cromer's views. The opponents of the Occupation are the only veritable patriots. If Lord Cromer's wishes for the welfare of the Egyptian people are sincere, he should permit them to occupy many of the important positions now reserved for Englishmen, and reduce the expenses caused by the Occupation. The Egyptians were the first civilised race in the history of the world and are to-day as capable of assimilating modern civilisation as the Japanese or the English themselves. The future will show their capacity beyond dispute.

div.head: SYRIAN PROTESTANT COLLEGE. 36th ANNUAL COMMENCEMENT EXERCISES.
div.p: -For over three decades the Syrian Protestant College stood, as it were, on an eminence as a beacoYof knowledge shedding a growing light on Syria, and in its later phases of development it has' plainly become one of the most potent educational factors in the Near East. One has but to glance at the latest edition of its prospectuses, of Which à judicious distribution is annual'y made, to realise the magnitude of its infiuen o and the scope of its field of action. This magnifioent institution recruits its army.of about * 700 stadents from various countries. Its radius of power extends from Armenia in the East to Greece and the Ionian Isles in the West, and from Asia Minor in the down to Egypt in the South. But ils influence has been mostly felt in Egypt, directly through the preponderant number 6Î seekers for knowledge that the Land of ' the haraohs has always supplied, and indirectly but no less mightily through the Syrian settlers who constitute a strong intellectual element in Egyptian life, and who, under the strong, capable, and judioious guidance of British rulers, are contributing largely to the progress of the country. Therefore any event of public character in this birthplace of learning should not fail to appeal to the interest of the readers of the "Gazette."

The commencement exercises this year began on Saturday, 24th June, ten days earlier than the usual and traditional time. This has been determined by the early arrival of the Imperial Medical Commission from Constantinople. Although the exercises commenced on Saturday yet they may be considered to have been publicly inaugurated by the Baccalaureate service on Sunday, when President Howard Bliss delivered his annual valedictory and exhortatory address to the medical and pharmaceutical graduates. The scene was, as it may easily be imagined, one calculated to call forth deep and stirring emotions and inspire thoughts of the noblest kind, and the young President's fiery eloquence rose splendidly to the occasion. The meeting was well attended by students and many of the public. The blessing was fitly given by the old President Emeritus, whose appearance in public functions at the college is still inspiring and recalls to the hearts of older students happy memories of the godd old days.

The exercises closed on Wednesday with the ceremony of thé distribution of prizes And diplomas. The principal and striking féature of that day was the processional march. At Ada Dodge Hall the procession, consisting of the old graduates, the faculty, and the staff of teachers, formed* and proceeded to the Memorial Hall at 3.30 p m. preceded by the American Consul and the Imperial Medical Commission. The President and members of the Faculty wore their "academic gowns, and as it marched forth with measured step and took ito-feeats on the platform in the Memorial Hall* the procession presented a sight of unusual solemnity.

The closing event was a delightful entertainment on Wednesday evening at the President's, Marquand House, wound up by a series of hilarious and comic songs, lustily sung by a part of the American staff of teachers. The entertainment is given principally in honor of the Imperial Medical Commission, composed this year of General Mahmoud Hakki Pasha, a distinguished officer, Colonel Ahmed rehmi Bey, and Major Escret Roushen Bey. The reception wa3 held in the president's class-room, a hall of spacious dimensions, but which, owing to the large crowd, could afford only standing room. This, coupled with the orrid heat of June, made it particularly ncomfortable to the invités, and called forth uggestioiis from some of them for an enlargement of the hall, which would not be inadvisable considering the growing importance of the' college. Bat the welcome was so hearty, and there was such a general air of conviviality, that the heat and other little, discomforts were forgotten. Besides, to those blessed with a sense of hnmonr and that rare power of selfdetachment, there wag afforded a rich fund of /amusement by the presentation of the ijhtés to the Imperial Commission. This distinguished body was victimised by a presentation of almost all the large crowd of Quests, and for about half an hour there was something like a pantomimic show of a fFe of ladies and gedtlemen coming forward with lifferent degrees of grace and awkwardness to hake hands with* the three commissioners, who cut curious figures, repeating with lutomatic sameness the stiff, jerky, and deep German bow in reply to each introduction. After the ordeal they withdrew to the cooler recesses of the garden on which the hall opens, to indulge in timely refreshments and the necessary accompaniment of the fragrant weed.

These entertainments form a cheerful ending for the graduates of a year of hard study, wakeful anxieties, and stirring emotions, and no doubt they-procure the hospitable President and his charming wife many a farewell word of blessing from the grateful pupils who are to face the hard realities of life.

I had almost forgotten to add that 28 medical students were presented to the Commission for the final examination. Of these one did not complete his examination, one failed to pass, 36 took the oath of office before the commission and received their oollege diplomas. Their Turkish diplomas will he sent to them later.
Nine pharmacy students were presented to the commissioners for final examination. Of these all passed pud took the oath and reomy-eft diplomas.

div.head: RAS-EL-BAR. THE EGYPTIAN MARGATE.
div.p: Now that the summer has begun in earnest, many dwellers in inland towns will be thinking of making a move soon to some favored spot by the seaside where the invigorating ocean breezes will once more brace the jaded residents of the interior. For those who have the means San Stefano is incomparably the Queen of Egyptian summer resorts,but-to those to whom money is a primary consideration, and others who prefer a free-and-easy and happy-go-lucky existence, I know of ho better place close at hand than Ras-el-Bar, not far from bamietta.

I very much doubt whether the frequenters of this little place, which springs into life with the advent of the great beat, would seek to qualify its attractions by comparison with those offered elsewhere, say at Ramleh or Port Said, but I do not hesitate to say that it possesses a charm of its own, and I am not surprised when I discern the same familiar faces there £®ar after year. '

» The season proper at this Egyptian Margate, if I may term it so, does not commence in earnest until the middle of July, and is in full 8 wing until about the end of September, iothat the hotel-keepers and others who minister to the wants of the strangers have, in a sense, to make hay while the sun shines, although, considering the shortness of the season, no one can say that the prices charged are exorbitant. The majority of the visitors are Levantines and Egyptians, leavened by a fair number of Europeans of all the nationalities that inhabit this country.

The hotels, if one can honor them with this name, and dwellings ajfe mainly if not entirely constructed of the native rush mat fastened to wooden uprights and are slighly raised from the land or ground in the same manner as bungalows in India. Naturally, in a country like Egypt, where rain is unknown for nine months at least of the year, snch habitations are possible, but one could not calmly contemplate what would happen to the whole place were it visited by a good monsoon 'rain of an hour's duration.

Of course, of amusements of the fashionable kind there are none to hegnile the time, but for those who love sea-bathing, fishing, and an bnt-of-door life, Ras-el-Bar is a small paradise. The bathing ui the best in Egypt, and eaoh hotel has a hnt wherein batherrssan undress and dress. There are a few shops, sujch as the inevitable bacals, a good barber, ^chemist, and last, hut not least, a branch post-office. There is also from June, to October a small body of police under the orders of a native officer.

» I should not omit to mention, for the information of would-be new-comers, who may like to give the place a trial, that there is a regular steam boat service that carries the mail between Damietta and Ras-el-Bar, the trip occupying about an hour and running in coincidence with the arrival of the passenger trains from Mansourah. Daring the busy season the Egyptian Railway Administration runs an express train weekly each way which starts from Cairb every Thursday.

div.head: THE CAIRO HOTELS.
div.p: In reference to the recent rise in the shares of the two leading hotel companies of Egypt, it is worth noticing that the principal reason of the rapid appreciation within the past few months of this class of securities is the enormous increase since two years or so in the value of the land on which the Grand Continental and the Savoy Hotels are built in the case of the Nungovich Hotels Company, and in the case of the Egyptian Hotels Company, of the land at Ghezireh, which has been and is being 3old at rapidly increasing prices,

The former company bought the New Hotel, now the Grand Continental, àboùt six years ago, including the land it stands on and the furniture it contained, for £105,000, which, at the time, was considered the lull value. The presentvalue of the land alone, which measures 11,000 squarè metres, at the modest price of £20 per square metre, represents an increase of no less than £4 per share on the entire share capital of the company, not reckoning the building, furniture and good-will of a concern that pays yearly dividends of ten per cent.

The Savoy Hotel, as it is, was bought about a year later than the other from Prince Djemil Pasha Toussoum,we believe for £55,000. The land is 5,000 square metres in extent, but owing to the' extraordinary increase in the price of land in the best part of the Ismailia quarter the site alone to-day is worth the fifty five thousand pounds, without counting the palatial buildings erected on it. This* repre-^ sente an increase in value of at least £2 per share on the whole of the share capital. With these figures before us can one wonder that the £4 shares of the Nungovich Hotels are now worth £10 or thereabouts, and those of the Egyptian Hotels at an equally high premium ? .

As we mentioned a few weeks back, the former company have pnrobased by preemption a portion of the estate of the late Sabet Pasha, adjoining the Savoy Hotel, and on the ground so acquired they are to erect additional buildings to accommodate the large and ever-increasing clientèle that patrorises this hotel during the winter season, besides enlarging the restaurant and making other mnoh-needed improvements.

div.head: THE SUBMERGED DREDGER,
div.p: Work on the submerged dredger "Pharaonrp' II." is now being rabidly pushed towards com- ' pletion. t learn that the vessel is to be raised by qaite a novel method,' which' should prove most interesting. As I noted some time back, she lies bn her side, and a kind of bed is being .dredged ont along her side, at the bottom'of which is to be placed a patent slip cradle. A cutting is to be made in the hank into which the dredger lying on the cradle is to be towed. div.head: THE FOURTH OF JULY AT MANSOURAH.
div.p: Mr. W. L. Lawton, of the Jewell Export Filter Co., having just completed the installation of a plant of these filters at the new waterworks in this town, entertained his numerous friends on the dahabieh "Ariadne," kindly lent for the occasion by Mr. Dale, yesterday. Anchored in mid-stream, the rigging dressed with the flags of all hâtions, that of the star-spangled banner predominating, with a tapestried awning overhead, and palm-branches arched over the columns around the sides, file dahabieh made a gay show by day. At night, the numberless coloured lights, strung on high amongst the rigging and all around, with their reflection on the waters, had quite a fairy-like appearance. On the island in mid-stream two cannon had been placed, the thunders of which were interrupted by the authorities, it being against the Government regulations to fire artillery within 250 metres of the town, but our courteous Moudir : kindly the fireworks, rockets, Roman candles, etc., on this special occasion, the first time, in the annals of Mansourah, that this American fête has been celebrated in such a public maimer. Unfortunately the members of the American Mission were absent, having been called away the previous day to attend a meeting at Alexandria, so that Mr. Lawton was the only citizen present, but he war a host in himself, and reoéîved his guests for afternoon tfh at 5 o'clock on the deck of the dahabieh. This fonction over the company crossed over to the island amid-stream, where the gentlemen entertained the ladies by engaging in athletic sports. On their return to the boat, they found a sumptuous dinner spread out on a table which had been prettily decorated with flowers and plants by Mrs. Dale. Toasts, songs, and musio followed to a late hour of the night.

Mr. Lawton was ably assisted in the efforts to celebrate his national fête-day by Messrs, McCrae, Anderson, and Holeman, whose hearty co-operation went far to make the affair the success that it was. During the evening, muoh was said in praise of our most energetic Moudir, Mustapha Pashà Maher, for the many improvements he has introduced into the town, amongst them the paving of the main streets, their present cleanliness and order, and the construction of a, carriage drive and promenade along the hanks of the river, south of the town into the open country. This drive is to be planted with trees, which will form a shady avenue*, A new street has already been commenced, orossing the town, and opening up a route from the river to the open fields by the cemeteries. Not only has the Moudir had "Beni Adam" at heart in his endeavours to benefit the town, but his establishment of a branch of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been so successful, with the active and able support of his officers, the police, and our veterinary surgeon Dr. Trydel, that it is an exception now-a-daysto fin da siok animal about the streets, and whereas the S.P.C.A's hospital was formerly crowded with siok beasts, many having to be shot, all the stalls are now often empty.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: After finishing last week and opening the present one in a state of "nerves," with weak prices all round, there was a general recovery on Tuesday, when it was realised that the Morocco scare had been very much overdone. The tendency now is decidedly better, the only uncertain factor being what effect the state of anarchy, which is spreading rapidly in Russia, may have on the Paris market. The rumours which have been current during the last two or three days as to, a new Japanese loan are apparently well founded, the amount spoken of being 30 millions more of 4 1/2 % stock, divided equally between London, New York, and Berlin, and offered at 91. Coming so close on the heels of the last issue, it cannot be so much the want of money that prompts this issue as a challenge of Credit, so to speak, and, perhaps, also the desire to get at the money market before the opponent does so.

There is little that is new to say about Egyptian stocks. Bank shares finish the week rather firmer, Nationals at 26 and Agriculturals at 13 5/8. Dairas are also taken better at 28 1/8. Mines are still dull and lifeless.

The remarks made by Lord Cromer last night, when dining at the Skinners' Company, in reference to new promotions in Egypt, are looked upon in the market as most satisfactory. It is felt that the Government can do so much to prevent wild-cat schemes, and his lordship's statement that "they will do their best to resist the invasion of the mere company-monger" is a strong assurance, at all events, that the investor will have a fair run for his money.

div.head: RELICS FROM SINAI AND EGYPT. LONDON UNIVERSITY COLLEGE EXHIBITION.
div.p: The exhibition opened last week at University College, London, of collections made during the past year by the working parties of the Egyptian Exploration Fund contains interesting relics from ground already broken.

Drs. Grenfell and Hunt, in searching among the rubbish heaps of Oxyrhynkos for papyri of Roman and especially early Christian ages, have found other interesting objects, such as vases with designs in reliefs and a richly coloured glaze, figures and dishes, carved ivory panels, bronze statuettes, such as a Demeter, admirably modelled, and an Aphrodite grasping Eros by the arm so roughly as to suggest coming chastisement. There are lamps, coins, and all the usual "finds," but the gem is a small marble head of Hera, exquisitely worked. Stone weapons are there in plenty from near Thebes, with "finds" from Lithom and other places, while on the walls hang numerous copies of figures and hieroglyphs, made by Mrs. Flinders Petrie and other ladies, from tombs, seven of which were opened for the purpose. As these become rarer year by year, by the influence of time, the ravages of treasure-seekers, and the transportations of whole structures to other countries, the value of such permanent records is sufficiently obvious.

But the results of investigations in the Sinaitic Peninsula are the most important feature of this year's exhibition. We have long known that, from very early days, its mines were worked by the Egyptians. Sculptures, stelae, hieroglyphic inscriptions, which have been partly deciphered, prove this nation to have held the country long before the Exodus. Professor Petrie's party worked in the turquoise mining district, that is, in the upper part of the Wady Maghara and especially at Sarabit el Khadem, near the western coast, well north both of Serbal and the traditional Mount Sinai. The gem is found in a red sandstone which is a little older than the chalk of England. Major Macdonald made an attempt to revive the industry about forty years ago, but found it unremunerative. He was followed, within the last decade, by a company, whose efforts were also, and more deservedly, not successful, for their reckless methods irreparably injured some of the most interesting Egyptian antiquities—and some mining is still done by the Arabs. Turquoises are not uncommon, but the majority are of little value. The mines, as we now learn, were open even in the first Egyptian dynasty, the oldest monument representing one of its kings, Mersekha, who flourished, according to Professor Petrie, about six thousand five hundred years ago, i.e., 4600 B.C., "clubbing" a captive chief. Other sculptures commemorate kings of he third dynasty, and dozens of inscriptions were cut between this date and the end of the twelfth dynasty—about 2500 B.C. Thus, many centuries before the Exodus, not a few before the days of Abraham, Sinai was in Egyptian occupation. Some have thought that copper also was worked about Sarabit el Khadem. That, however, Professor Petrie has proved to be a mistake ; the heaps of black material, supposed to be slag, are hematite, a natural iron ore, which, if coal were handy, might be valuable ; but the main copper works are six miles away, in the Wady Nasb.

Sarabit el Khadem was evidently an exceptionally holy place. On the edge of the upland, near the brow of a lofty cliff, are the ruins of a great temple, and the neighbouring hills are dotted over with tiny sanctuaries—all, probably, for the same purpose, revelation through dreams. These sanctuaries consist of a rough stone wall surrounding a larger upright block ; the one sheltering the sleepers from the wind, the other marking the spot where they might "see visions" and "dream dreams." Like the pillar set up by Jacob, these indicated a Bethel; the temple itself being evidently the most sacred spot of all. It is remarkable, not only for its progressive growth, but also for being Syrian in type, though Egyptian by construction. It is, of course, now in ruins, but a model gives an excellent idea of its original structure.

It was the sanctuary of the goddess Hathor, and her primitive shrine was a rook cave. This must have existed so far back as the third dynasty—or nearly seven thousand years ago; for the name of Seneferu, one of its kings, is still clear. Kings of the twelfth dynasty—or about 2500 B.C.—reconstructed the shrine and made a road, ornamented with stelæ, part of which still remains. Their successors of the eighteenth dynasty much enlarged it by adding a long vestibule with two small courts, curving with the contour of the hill-side and terminating in a gateway. This was about 1500 B.C., and at a later epoch a structure, cut up into a number of small chambers, was placed in front of this. The whole is enclosed by rude walls, which were added by Amen Hotep III. The neighbouring ground is covered with ashes, in great part remnants of sacrifices at least as old as the twelfth dynasty. In that shrine at first, in those chambers, when pilgrims became more numerous, the votaries slept, and it marked the holiest place, like the Kiblah of a mosque. But this temple has a feature still less Egyptian—two small courts, each of which has a stone basin for purification. Thus this characteristic feature of every Mohamedan mosque must have existed in Syrian worship fifteen centuries before the Christian era.

The site has yielded many interesting relics from the date of Seneferu onwards, not the least remarkable being the head of a statuette, in dark stone, representing Thyi, a queen of the eighteenth dynasty, well preserved and admirably executed. They also found some fragments of vases, with yellow-coloured designs in relife on a purple ground, recalling the Portland Vase. One represents King Ramesu III. in his harem, and thus is rather more than three thousand years old. It may seem, at first sight, strange that Egyptian kings should build sanctuaries for the gods of Syria, but local deities were not to be despised in their own lands, as we can see from a very curious record written about the year 1200 B.C, of which Professor Petrie gives a summary in the new Volume of his History of Egypt.

div.head:
LORD BEACONSFIELD'S FIRMNESS.
THE SECRET HISTORY OF THE BERLIN CONGRESS.
div.p: Mr. A. N. Cumming was a fellow patient with Lord Rowton at Wiesbaden in 1898, and they had many talks about Lord Beaconsfield and the political questions of the time. Freed by the death of Lord Rowton from the condition laid down that he would publish nothing of their conversation during his lifetime, Mr. Cumming has an interesting article in the July "Nineteenth Century" on "The Secret History of the Treaty of Berlin," as narrated by Lord Rowton.

Within a few minutes of the arrival in Berlin of Lord Beaconsfield with Lord Rowton to attend the famous Congress, a message arrived from Prince Bismarck, and at 10.30 at night the English Premier called upon the Chancellor. Lord Rowton waited outside, strolling about under the trees.

"Whilst I was walking there, what was my surprise to hear my own name called out, 'My dear Monty !' I turned in astonishment, and beheld Count Schouvaloff, who wasthen, as you know, the Russian Ambassador in London. We were old and intimate friends in London, where we saw a great deal of each other. 'My dear fellow,' said he, 'what in the world are you doing here ?' I replied, 'I am waiting for Lord Beaconsfield, who is now closeted with Prince Bismarck.' His face fell. Obviously he had come upon the same errand, and Lord Beaconsfield had forestalled him. That was the first move, and I have no doubt at all that already at that first interview Bismarck had taken the measure of his man in Lord Beaconsfield, and I traced from that a great deal of what subsequently occurred."

At the Congress the English representatives put forward four points which were described as an ultimatum for the acceptance of Russia. The Russians declared they were so important that they must refer them to the Tsar himself, and a diplomat of high rank must proceed to St. Petersburg for his Majesty's orders. The Congress, therefore, adjourned.

"On the morning after that decision," Lord Rowton told Mr. Cumming, "Lord Beaconsfield came into my room. He said, 'I have quite made up my mind what to do. It seems to me impossible for Russia to concede these points, and, if they refuse, I have sketched out my plan. We will return to England at once.' Arrived in London, he would make his report to the Queen. 'A declaration of war will follow.'"

He requested Lord Rowton to make the necessary arrangements for the journey to England. To get there within the time essential to Lord Beaconsfield's plans, a special train from Cologne was required; and this Lord Rowton ordered by telegram. This telegram "was the turning point of the whole affair."

"The Congress met again for a final decision on this matter at the appointed time. Whilst the meeting was going on I waited outside as usual. After a sitting of a couple of hours the door opened, and I noticed particularly that the Russians came out first, Schouvaloff at their head. Lord Beaconsfield, as was his custom, came out last of all, and, when he was going away, he took my arm and said, 'My dear Corry, I have seen what I never expected to see. Russia has given way on all four points.' "We subsequently discovered, of course, that my telegram to the station-master at Cologne had been promptly transmitted to Prince Bismarck. He thereupon saw that Lord Beaconsfield was in earnest. He knew, and this we did not discover until a good deal later, that, as a matter of fact, the Russians had received orders from the Tsar practically to submit to anything rather than go to war with England. He knew that, but we did not. Both at the first interview, of which I told you, and after that lucky telegram of mine to Cologne, he saw that Lord Beaconsfield was in earnest. He had taken the measure of the man ; he told the Russians what the fact was, and the result was that they gave in.

"I may tell you further that the Russian pretext that they must consult the Tsar upon the question of those four points was a mere blind. They did send off a messenger, one of their highest diplomats, but we learned later on that he left the train at Königsberg, and did not proceed any farther."

div.head:
THE BAGDAD RAILWAY.
THE SECOND ANNUAL REPORT.
div.p: The report of the second year's activity of the Bagdad Railway has just been published for 1904. It deals mainly with the construction of the section of the line from Konia to Eregli and Bulguriu ; this is the first section of the Bagdad Railway; it is 135 miles in length, and starting from Konia, has eleven stations inclusive of Konia and Bulguriu. The work of laying down the line made such good progress, that the line could be thrown open to traffic on October 25, 1904, and by December 31 the gross receipts amounted to £2,776, which is at the rate of £77 16s. 9d. per kilometre per year. The kilometre-guarantee of £3,894, due from the Turkish Government under the terms of the convention, was paid in full by the Dette Publique Ottomane in February, and the net profits for 1904 amounted to £32,205. On the whole, the German Press maintains almost absolute silence concerning the progress of the laying down of the Bagdad Railway.

div.head: THE SISTINE CHAPEL.
div.p: It is said that the cracks in the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel which for closeon four centuries have caused anxiety are to some extent fraudulent, having been painted in a kind of grim humour by Michael Angelo when he decorated the ceiling,

Whether the story is apooryphal is difficult to say, but, at any rate, the false fissures, if there are such, have been accompanied by real cracks of late, and all who have seen or have heard of the Sistine Chapel will be relieved to learn that the repairs which have been in progress have just been completed.

For many, of course, Pope Sixtus the Fourth's Chapel owes its interest to the conclaves which it has witnessed, those secret meetings into which three score and ten priests enter as equals to choose from among them one to sit on the Chair of the Fisherman. Chanting the "Veni Creator," they go in, these princes of the Church, in their crimson robes, and they come out as they went in, all save one, who has changed his red robes for white, his hat for a tiara, his crozier for the cross and keys.

Nobleman and peasant, statesman and saint, all in their turn have come out from the Sistine Chapel, elected to hold office in the longest dynasty the modern world has seen, to be crowned with the triple crown while "Sic transit gloria mundi" is still ringing in their ears.

But apart from all this, there are few who can think of the Sistine Chapel save as the culminating point in the art of the Renaissance, as the epitome of the great revival when Florence taught Rome and Rome still taught the world.

Perugino and Botticelli, Ghirlandajo and Signorelli are among the men whom Sixtus commissioned to paint frescoes on the walls, on the one side from the Old Testament and on the other from the New, so that incidents from the life of Christ might be confronted by scenes from the lives of those who in the Old Law acted as His types.

Under these frescoes of the great Florentine masters, the last word, one may say, of the quattrocento, were to have hung tapestries, Raphael's cartoons for some of which are to be seen in London at South Kensington. But it is Michael Angelo who has added most glory to the Sistine Chapel in the prophets and sybils which he painted on the roof, and in the great "Last Judgment" at the east end over the High Altar.

He who had been hailed as having inherited the mantle of Phidias and Praxiteles, who was architect of the great new basilica, most perforce be made to earn other laurels, so thought Pope Julius, by limning the roof of the chapel in the Vatican.

Everyone knows how the great master who declared that painting in oils was an occupation for women and idlers spent four years on the roof of the chapel. While he was engaged upon it he refused admission to all, but the Pope, thinking that he, at any rate, could watch the work, was summarily treated by having paint dropped on his head from the scaffolding above. Julius II., however, recognised the painter's genius and did not resent his eccentricities.
Another example of the grim vengeance of Buonarotti occurred when Paul III.'s ceremonaire pointed out to the Pontiff the scandal which the nude figures in the "Last Judgment" would give.

The Pope took the hint, and commissioned someone to paint in drapery over the most naked figures; Michael Angelo had his revenge by painting a portrait of the Master of Ceremonies with ass's ears in Hell ; the latter complained to the Pope in order that he might have the figure removed, but Paul declared that it was impossible, had he been in Purgatory something might have been done, but being in Hell there was no release. More than two centuries and a half have passed, and not only the hand of time, but the blackening of tapers and of "the good strong, thick; stupefying incense smoke" have left their mark, and have dimmed the colours of the fresco, but Massei Biagio, like Midas with ass's ears, still writhes in Hell.

It was nearly 70 years after Sixtus IV. had begun the chapel that Michael Angelo laid down his brush on completing the Last Judgment ; the first della Rovera Pope had been succeeded by the infamous Innocent VIII., who in his tarn was replaced by the yet more infamous Alexander VI.

After the Borgia came the second della Rovera—Julius III., the warrior pontiff who would fain be painted, not with a book, but with a sword in his hand, "for," said he, "I know nought of letters." Then came two Medici Popes, Leo X. and Clement VII., and finally under the Farnese Pope, Paul III., the great chapel was finished.

It was the last, as it was the most supreme, example of didactic painting. In it was reached the climax of art which aimed at setting forth the mysteries of religion and the history of the Church that all might see, and seeing, understand.

All through Italian art in the Middle Ages and until the Renaissance we find painting made the handmaid of religion, representing the symbolism of the Scriptures or the lives of the saints, and if one excepts the preaching of the friars, acting as the main source of instruction in religion which offered itself to the people.

But with revival of learning the practice died out Pagan influences when acting on men who lacked the genius of a Buonarotti produced a group of painters in whom what was gained in technical knowledge made no amends for what was lost in the sensuous appeal which the less perfect painters by their very simplicity effected.

And before long came the great bathos in the history of Italian art, within fifty years ofits climax was reached its anticlimax. Scarcely was Michael Angelo cold in his grave; one may say, when the great horde of mannerists swept over the churches of Italy, covering with gilding and crude colours what formerly had been dignified by simplicity, leaving their Assumptions or Ascensions in every church with pompous schemes worked out with wretched skill, leaving an impression on the mind of thousands of cupids rolling about in a company where they alone were not involved in bellying drapery.

div.head: GENERAL GALLIENI'S REPLY.
div.p: The Governor-General of Madagascar is not only the most able administrator France possesses, but as is so often the case, he is a man with a sense of humour as well. Owing to former scandals, a very salutary rule has been made in France that no officer shall draw pay for two or more appointments at the same time. But General Gallieni is at one and the same time drawing pay as Governor-General, as a general officer, and as General commanding the troops in Madagascar, so that on the whole he receives 180,000 francs, or rather over £7,000 per annum, which, after all, is not too much for the great services which he has rendered to his country. But this abnormal state of things worried M. Dumergue, the late Minister for the Colonies, though he did not venture to order General Gallieni to conform to the role, because the General is a power at the Colonial Office, and is, moreover, considered indispensable in Madagascar, in spite of the fact that two or three highly-placed men are doing all they can to step into his places M. Domergue, therefore, wrote privately to the Governor-General, and begged him to see that no officer in the Madagascar army of occupation transgressed the role. The Minister flattered himself that he had put the case very cleverly, but he had to acknowledge himself beaten when he got the delightful answer :— "Sir, I have the honor to inform you that not one of the officers under my orders is drawing double pay." General Gallieni, therefore, continued to receive his 180,000 francs.

div.head: DOG-BITE AS BLACKMAIL.
div.p: A novel and singular system of fraud has just been brought to light at Nuremberg. A man named Niell conceived the idea of levying blackmail by means which have hitherto escaped the attention of the most astute of his precursors. He made a regular inventory of all fairly well-to-do people in the city who kept dogs, and "worked" them in turn district by district. His plan was to watch for circumstances which might give colour to his story, and then going to the dog's owner to complain that he had been bitten, showing some slight abrasion on the leg to clinch his story. He never asked for money, but always threatened a summons, and with equal regularity accepted the pecuniary offers made to him "to settle the thing." Niell had kept his business running steadily for two years before he fell into the hands of the police.

div.head: TUNIS IN A WATER FAMINE.
div.p: One scarcely likes to think of a large European population in an African city, placed on an extremely limited water supply in an African summer. That, however, is the prospect which threatens Tunis. The extent and rapidity with which the European population has increased has entirely outstripped even the estimated supply, which, on the other hand, to aggravate matters has not realised the estimate by quite a third. As if this was not enough, such water as there is bears traces of naphthous contamination. At present the supply is cut off for 12 hours a day, and the hours will have to be still further restricted. If the heats are great, the consequences to the public health may be terrible.

div.head: PIGMIES AT ST. STEPHEN'S.
div.p: Five of the African pigmies now on a visit to London were entertained at the House of Commons yesterday week. There were four men and one woman. The former were dressed as Haussas, each wearing a blue Norfolk jacket, blue cloth breeches, black putties, and red fez. They were armed with small bows and arrows and with spears. The woman was in a white robe relieved with colour and wore a necklet of beads. As they stood beneath the lofty dome of the central ball, and later against the high palace wall of the terrace, the graceful minuteness of the little people was effectively seen.

A gentleman who has travelled widely in Africa spoke with some authority in associating the visitors with the true race of pigmies. "What dear little baby men," was the instructive exclamation of a lady bystander. Dr. Hutchinson, M.P., who received the lilliputian strangers, entertained them to tea on the terrace, their preference being towards sardines, hard-boiled eggs, and chocolates. They were photographed by Sir Benjamin Stone.

div.head: ABYSSINIAN CONVENTION.
div.p: The French Government, Reuter's Agency is informed, has still under consideration the counter proposals put forward by Italy with reference to the negotiations now in progress between Great Britain, France, and Italy for the conclusion of a convention dealing with Abyssinian affairs. Fresh proposals were formulated by France and presented to the Marquis of Lansdowne last month, and were duly communicated to the Government in Rome, whose reply was received a few days ago and communicated to the French Government. It should be stated that perfect agreement exists between the three Governments regarding the preservation of their interests in Ethiopia on the basis of Abyssinian independence, and that the proposals and counterproposals referred to are connected merely with matters of detail. That a convention has not already been signed is probably due to the fact that other more pressing questions have been engaging the attention of the French Foreign Office.

div.head: RISE IN PRICE OF WOOL.
div.p: War in the Far East has been partly responsible for a remarkable rise in the price of wool, due to the large purchases of clothing and blankets by the Japanese Government. Wool has advanced from threepence to sixpence a pound on the prices three years ago. This, to the owners of large sheep farms, means, of course, large fortunes. It benefits Australia, unfortunately, but little, for the high prices are partly due to the drought and disease in that country during the last year ; but the demand in the United States is steadily increasing, so the industry in the colonies may eventually become a prosperous one. Needless to say, the change is highly unwelcome to the manufacturer and the purchaser of carpets and other woollen materials.
